p: Melatonin has been found to be involved in numerous different processes in all organisms investigated so far. It exhibits pleiotropic biological activities in phylogenetically diverse species. Some of these activities are mediated by G-protein-coupled and nuclear receptors (Reppert 1997; Dubocovich et al. 1999; Imbesi et al. 2009), whereas others are receptor-independent, such as melatoninâ€™s interactions with free radicals and activities mediated by its bioactive metabolites (Reiter 1996; Tan et al. 2002; Schaefer and Hardeland 2009). A common characteristic in all the pleiotropic functions of melatonin is that it is involved in setting the timing of all processes (Cassone and Natesan 1997).
